description: {"blocks":[{"key":"623gh","text":"    Genome editing in human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) offers a potential tool for studying gene functions in disease models and correcting genetic mutations for cell-based therapy. Precise transgene insertion in hiPSCs represents a significant challenge. In the past decade, viral transduction has been widely used due to its high transduction efficiency; however, it can result in random transgene integration and variable transgene copy numbers. Non-viral-based strategies are generally safer but limited by their low transfection efficiency in hiPSCs. Recently, genome engineering using adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors has emerged as a promising gene delivery approach due to AAVs’ low immunogenicity, toxicity, and ability to infect a broad range of cells. The following protocol describes the workflow for genome editing in hiPSCs using CRISPR/Cas9 ribonucleoproteins (RNPs) combined with the recombinant AAV serotype 6 (AAV6) donor vectors to introduce a gene of interest (GOI) fused with mCherry fluorescent reporter gene into the AAVS1 safe harbor site. This approach leads to efficient transgene insertion and is applicable to precise genome editing of hiPSCs or other types of stem cells for research purposes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Production of the AAV6 particles harboring GOI-mCherry
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"n2gn","text":"The AAV6 production is carried out by co-transfecting the pAAV donor plasmid and the pDGM6 helper plasmid into HEK293T cells. The donor plasmid contains inverted terminal repeat (ITR), left homology arm of the AAVS1 gene (AAVS1-LHA), EF1α promoter, GOI-mCherry, polyA tail, right homology arm of the AAVS1 gene (AAVS1-RHA), and ITR. The total size of the two ITRs is 290 bp while the size of each homology arm is 300 bp. The pDGM6 helper plasmid vector consists of the AAV6 cap genes, the AAV2 rep genes, and the adenovirus helper genes (Fig 1).","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":210,"length":6},{"style":"italic","offset":300,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5gklq","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c0iqh","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cbff4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E6C95B20961811ECBC4C2F693EB08DBC","height":137,"id":260622,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":71,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"f6vf","text":"Fig 1.Schematic diagram of pAAV donor plasmid and pDGM6 helper plasmid.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Fig S1.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h8ssbprtx.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h8sqbprtx.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h8srbprtx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h8spbprtx.webp","width":550}}}}
